message:
AGV members Tejus Gupta and Harshit Sikchi presented their paper 'Robust Lane Detection using Multiple Features'  at IV 2018 under the guidance of Prof DrDebashish Chakravarty, held in China this week.

Intelligent Vehicle symposium is a premier international conference on autonomous driving technologies sponsored by the IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Society.
(http://www.2018iv.org)

Congratulations to them from the entire team!

(Link for the short demonstration:
https://youtu.be/TzlBsWBXbVs)

story: AGV shared Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur's post.
message: AGV shared Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur's post. The day couldn't have started on a better note for KGP! The research groups of our institute seem to be on a roll! In what comes as a matter of pride for KGP student community and a testimony of brilliance of its research fraternity, Autonomous Ground Vehicle (AGV) research group, IIT Kharagpur have secured second position in 26th International Ground Vehicle Competition (IGVC) held at Oakland University in Rochester, Michigan on June 1 - June 4, 2018. A total of 43 teams across India, Japan, USA, Canada and Istanbul had registered for this prestigious navigation challenge. But our team gave the best of the colleges which included the likes of University of British Columbia, Georgia Institute of Technology, University of Michigan-Ann Arbor, Ohio University etc., a run for their money. 7 teams from India contested in it including those from IIT Madras and IIT Kanpur. Team AGV finished as Runner-Up, while the winners were the team CART (Center for Applied Research and Technology), Inc. at Bluefield State College, USA. They needed to make a bot which can follow the lanes avoiding the obstacles by following given GPS coordinates. They designed forward wheel drive bot with castor at back. The one travelling the maximum distance of the given arena would go on to win the competition. Their bot travelled a remarkable 260 feets in the process of finishing as Runner Ups. The entire AGV team had started assembling and modelling of the bot from December itself and with ample support from Prof. DrDebashish Chakravarty of Mining Engineering Department, their efforts got better and better. As their bot scaled past the obstacles following GPS coordinates, it was in a way metaphoric of the AGV team scaling new heights with their efforts. And a special credit also goes to the first year members who worked relentlessly and contributed with great zeal and enthusiasm. The Intelligent Ground Vehicle Competition (IGVC) is an annual international robotics competition for teams of undergraduate and graduate students. Teams design and build an autonomous ground vehicle capable of completing several difficult challenges. To know more about AGV, visit: www.agv.iitkgp.ac.in Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates the entire team of AGV on this remarkable feat and hopes that the level and quality of research continues to set new standards in the upcoming days.

story: AGV added 4 new photos — with Shashank Mishra.
message:
A workshop was conducted on 7th and 8th October for the students of AGV, sponsored by Nugenix. The workshop was taken by Mr Lentin Joseph, who is the Founder of QboticsLabs and Roboacademy. He is also one of the most renowned author of books like "ROS Robotics Projects", "Mastering ROS" and "Learning Robotics". 

AGV IIT Kharagpur extends its vote of thanks to Mr Aditya Marathe and Mr Lentin Joseph for the successful conduction of the workshop. These are some of the glimpses of the workshop.

Self-driving cars are coming — sooner than you think. But when will we get there, and how will we get there?
 
Two terms for the transition have become standard in the auto industry. There's the "evolutionary" path to autonomous vehicles, where today's cars get self-driving features bit by bit — Tesla's autopilot feature, for example. And then there's the "revolutionary" path. That's where totally self-driving cars, like the ones Google is working on, start as test vehicles and become more mainstream as they can drive in more places.
There's an ongoing debate over which path is the safer one. But these paths will eventually converge.
 
Today's most advanced semi-autonomous features can be found in Tesla's and a few other cars that allow drivers to take their hands off the steering wheel on a highway. Using a series of sensors and cameras, cars can also merge, self-park, stay within a lane and brake as needed.
 
This tech works particularly well for commercial trucks that operate on highways. Companies like Peloton and NXP are "platooning" trucks — tying them together through a vehicle-to-vehicle communication system. A "pilot" truck drives while those behind can sit and relax.

Google and Ford are testing self-driving cars in structured environments like test tracks, as well as cities with relatively light traffic, like Austin, Texas and Mountain View, Calif. Vehicles travel at slow speeds — up to 25 miles an hour — while gathering data on pedestrians and human drivers; they are also starting to drive at night, and in rain and snow.
 
By 2019, Driver-assistance features will get more sophisticated, and will sync up with GPS and navigation. So a driver should be able to input a destination while driving on a highway, turn on adaptive cruise control and let the car drive itself. When it gets to the appropriate exit, the car will return control to the driver.

In the USA, NHTSA (NATIONAL HIGHWAYS TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION) has begun working on rules for testing and deployment of fully autonomous vehicles, without a driver, across the country. In the meantime, companies like Google will be racking up miles to gather data about every single type of situation a self-driving vehicle might encounter; mapping companies will gather as much 3D data in major cities as possible. Car makers and tech companies will have to make sure light detection and ranging (lidar) and radar sensors, as well as cameras and GPS, can work together, while ensuring that each component can function independently if one of them fails
.
Companies will also be testing vehicles in all climates and environments, including rain and snow. They'll also test cars in more places, moving from test tracks and low-density cities to roads with more foot and vehicle traffic. 
 
Commercial trucks will likely be the first vehicles to hit the road autonomously, if state and federal regulators give them them the go-ahead to work on highways. 
 
Here is one such article on the legislation making rounds in the Congress for federal rules on self driving cars to supersede state and local regulations :
 
https://www.wired.com/story/congress-autonomous-self-driving-car-regulations/

3rd Feb | 6 PM |  V1

Be there. We will give you a sneak peek at the amazing work we do at AGV. Looking forward to your questions!

Attention Freshers:

Want to be part of the team that is building India's first Self-driving Car?

3rd Feb | 6 PM |  V1

Be there. We will give you a sneak peek at the amazing work we do at AGV. Looking forward to your questions!

At AGV we make use of the latest technology to constantly push the frontier of research in Autonomous Cars in India. We are happy to present to you a view of the IIT Kharagpur campus you have never seen before. 

Details for the nerds: These are images from a 3D Point Cloud map of the campus we generated with the Velodyne LiDAR. We will make use of the map to autonomously drive the Mahindra e2o car provided to us by Mahindra Rise.
